Quantum theory is a branch of mathematics, and as such it is subject to the same mathematical foundations as other branches of mathematics. The foundations of quantum theory have been the subject of intense debate for the past century. In this paper we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between categories. The equivalence preserves the basic structure of the theory, including the basic mathematical objects, the basic mathematical operations, and the basic mathematical theorems. The approach provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is both mathematically rigorous and philosophically neutral.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism. (Abridged)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis and has led to a high number of deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this disease, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has been shown to be able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear import of transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of transcription factors and, as a consequence, to impair the expression of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of the immune system and could lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the proton channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the proton channel will further our understanding of the proton channel and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the proton channel

The world’s food production systems are already challenged by climate variability, and climate change will make the situation worse. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize production and yields, and the impact of climate change on the stability of maize production and yields, in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero in the top four maize-exporting countries, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is one of the most enduring questions in ecology. In this study, we show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the degree to which diverse species partition food resources. We show that, in a semiarid African savanna, the degree to which species consume different plant species is highly correlated with the degree to which they consume different plant types. Moreover, we show that the degree to which species consume different plant types is often greater than the degree to which they overlap in their consumption of those plant types. These results suggest that the coexistence of species in a world of limited resources may be more complex than previously thought.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the extent to which they have already laid off workers and closed their doors. We also explore the financial fragility of small businesses and the extent to which they anticipate accessing the CARES Act. Finally, we assess the effects of the pandemic on small businesses by comparing the impact of loans relative to grants.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris on the open ocean surface. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would have important implications for the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the human body. It is responsible for a wide variety of functions, including control of blood pressure, regulation of inflammation, and control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and its function is controlled by the integration of multiple lines of information. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is characterized by a small-world configuration, which is a combination of high local efficiency and high global efficiency. The small-world configuration is a property of many complex networks and is associated with robustness and resilience.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the data needs of the public health community have been enormous. We have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This infrastructure is intended to empower research and decision-making, and to help the public health community to better understand and respond to the pandemic.

This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host’s diet and the host’s behavior. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of herbivores is not well understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome can have a significant impact on the health of the host. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut microbes that have been overlooked in the past, synthesize natural products that could be used by the host to maintain a healthy microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to a reduced capacity to produce energy in the nucleus accumbens. These findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our results have implications for understanding the role of personality traits in social behavior and for the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a challenging task. The use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors, some of which are unachievable by a single material. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is highly variable and is influenced by a variety of factors, including age, sex, and genetic factors. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is expressed in erythroid cells, can affect the expression of hemoglobin in human erythrocytes.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the survival rate of cancer patients has not improved in the last 40 y. The development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis. Thus, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have some side effects. We show that the most common drugs in this class activate a pathway that promotes vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that declines accelerated on private industrial lands where clearcutting continued. The NWFP also failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations, which continued to decline on federal land. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care, and that it is more accessible, exhibits higher solubility, and has a higher binding affinity to the ribosome. The predicted best compound is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The predicted best compound is also more active than the current standard of care against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The results provide a unique perspective on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock, which rapidly adapted to the changing hydroclimate regime following the MPT. The extreme hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock, and the habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin levels and phase-delays the circadian clock, and that this has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is a critical time in the Earth’s history, but the cause of the YDB is still debated. One hypothesis is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with terrestrial Os, and the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania are consistent with their source being in the 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell responses, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance and in the development of autoimmunity is still debated. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, and revealed that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom. We propose that the evolution of symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, and the subsequent diversification of specialized herbivores, was a key factor in the evolution of beetle diversity.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a key factor in the success of the current COVID-19 pandemic response. However, many antibodies lose their neutralizing activity against emerging variants. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve antibody neutralization against variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of the human species.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is the only known site of evolution of the language faculty. Despite its importance, the brain’s language system is one of the most difficult cognitive functions to study, because of the difficulty of measuring the activity of the billions of neurons in the brain. Here, we show that deep learning models trained on large datasets of speech and text can predict neural activity in the human brain during language processing. These models are thus a powerful tool for studying the brain’s language system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of deep learning, but rather a consequence of the particular problems that have been studied so far. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, and we introduce a new class of neural networks that we prove are stable. Our results provide a classification theory for neural networks, and they have implications for the design of neural networks in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the limits of science. The pandemic is caused by a virus, which is a biological entity. The virus is spread by people, who are biological entities. The behavior of biological entities is determined by their biology, which is determined by their environment, which is determined by their biology, and so on. This is a classic example of a feedback loop, which is a mathematical concept. The mathematical concept is not the same as the biological phenomenon.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy from Mexico, and compared it with that of the better-characterized M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions, despite having diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago. This suggests that the two bacteria are remarkably conserved and still cause similar diseases. (Abridged)

The evolution of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of fundamental physics. It is also of great relevance for the development of quantum technologies. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. Our result is based on a combination of integrability, quasiparticle picture, and the knowledge of the steady state. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a general framework for the study of entanglement dynamics in isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and the search for a vaccine is ongoing. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant animal model. This vaccine candidate could be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, this study shows that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, could have been the primary vectors of the disease. This would have important implications for the control of the disease, as it would have been easier to control the spread of plague if it was spread by fleas rather than rats.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which is more fundamental for the processing power of the brain, has been largely ignored. This study fills this gap by using the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuron numbers across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate many cellular processes. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled, and they can be cross-linked into networks. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key component of many cellular processes, including cytokinesis, cell migration, and vesicle trafficking. However, the mechanism by which it disassembles filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that the ADF/cofilin-induced torque on filament segments that are held between two anchoring points enhances severing by 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in many cellular processes. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that induce torque on dynamic polymers.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of these two sugars have been unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is also a unique case in terms of its settlement history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also reflected in the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island, which is sex biased and heterogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people, and that the observation of others’ negative experiences constitutes a negative experience for people. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social media platforms and for our understanding of the influence of others on our emotions. They also suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is the primary vehicle for transferring genetic information from the genome to the protein synthesis machinery. The vast majority of mRNAs are translated, but the rate of translation is highly variable and can be influenced by a variety of factors. Here we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can modestly alter the rate of translation and the products of translation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have a subtle effect on the translation of mRNAs, and that this effect can be amplified by the ribosome. These findings have implications for understanding the regulation of translation and the role of mRNA modifications in the control of protein synthesis. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. These associations are robust to the inclusion of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to the measurement of worthwhile ratings over a 4-y period. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most studied topics in biology. This work provides a quantitative analysis of the factors that have driven the evolution of body size in mammals, and the results are consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a common size of ∼500 kg by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that this is not the case in mouse airway cells, where the antiviral defense response is less efficient at cool temperature. Instead, the replication of rhinovirus is favored at cool temperature due, in part, to a more efficient replication of the virus itself at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines. (PsycINFO Database Record

The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause disease by a variety of mechanisms, including the production of toxins and the formation of biofilms. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. We demonstrate that pili-mediated surface sensing results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which in turn can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa uses pili as a sensor and as a regulator of its virulence. Understanding the mechanisms used by this pathogen to sense surfaces may lead to the development of new strategies to combat infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and this trend is expected to continue. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface water are poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into wildlife and the reemergence of the virus. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and could serve as a reservoir for the virus. Our findings highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to monitor the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 and to mitigate the risk of spillback into wildlife. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. (PsycINFO Database Record

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The paper examines the problems associated with building large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD cases. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and are responsible for the initiation of the AD-associated immune response. We also demonstrate that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. View Full-Text

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in human history. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken comes from the archaeological record of the Near East, where the species was first domesticated. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens comes from the archaeological record of the Southern Levant, where the species was first domesticated. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the Southern Levant dates to the Hellenistic period, and that the species was already widely exploited in Europe by the first century B.C.E.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that involves the formation of a folding intermediate. The intermediate is a transient state that is not part of the native conformation. The intermediate is not a global minimum of the free energy, but it is a local minimum. The folding intermediate is a key step in the folding process. The folding intermediate is a key step in the unfolding process. The folding intermediate is a key step in the binding of a substrate. The folding intermediate is a key step in the binding of a ligand. The folding intermediate is a key step in the binding of a drug.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA transcripts. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, RppH, has a unique preference for Np4-capped 5′ ends, and that this enzyme is capable of deprotecting those termini in a manner distinct from its normal function. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the development of new antibiotics. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce the severity of sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function. Here, we demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and proliferation in sepsis. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, despite external perturbations, and is characterized by a critical state. SOC is observed in a wide variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire fronts, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be improved by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical strain sensor, and that it can be used as a phase-transition thermometer. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. View Full-Text

The discovery of antifungal peptides is a major advance in the field of plant disease control. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, and its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We combined proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female axis is characterized by a dynamic process of protein association and dissociation. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to the platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) receptor to promote platelet adhesion and activation. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to the receptor-ligand complex switches the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of mutations in VWF and with the effects of force on VWF binding to platelets. The results suggest that the A1 domain of VWF is in a conformational switch that is regulated by force. This mechanism may be important for other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately connected to human health. The viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, however, because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which is the first of its kind. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to advance the field of human microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability of ACI is inadequate. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from isotopic evidence, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. Ion channels are composed of a protein backbone and a pore gate. The pore gate is responsible for ion flow and is the main target of drug development. Ion channels have two types of pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The BK channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to alter the physical properties of the red blood cell membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up a number of exciting avenues for future research. (Abridged)

Diamond is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including quantum devices, optical components, and sensors. However, its properties are sensitive to external factors, such as temperature and strain. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, and back to a semiconductor, by applying a small strain. This opens up a new way to control the properties of diamond, which can be used for applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host defense and disease outcome is unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We also show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on the spread of influenza virus. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in gamma power, followed by a sudden decrease whenever the word could be merged into a phrase. This suggests that the brain performs a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings may help to explain the brain’s ability to understand and produce language.

Vertebrates have two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique perspective on the regulation of redundant genes and their importance in tissue-specific functions.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. It is associated with a number of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers. The causes of obesity are complex and include genetic and environmental factors. However, it is clear that the brain plays a critical role in the development of obesity. Here we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all plants. However, the amount of N2 fixed by plants is only about 1% of the total atmospheric input. This is due to the fact that the majority of plants do not have the ability to fix N2. Therefore, the development of a system that can provide plants with N2-fixing bacteria would be a major step forward in the sustainable use of this essential element. Here, we describe the development of a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria. This system can be used to control the activity of bacteria in the soil, and thus to control the amount of N2 fixed by the bacteria. This work represents a major step forward in the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. The results from our analysis suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. Recombinant subunit vaccines based on proteins are well-established, proven interventions with multiple safe and efficacious commercial examples. These types of vaccines are suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing to yield billions of doses annually, minimizing their manufacturing cost. Here we report an engineered sequence variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity after a single dose in mice compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered protein can be presented on a virus-like particle, reducing weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a foundation for the development of a vaccine candidate that may be used in the global fight against COVID-19. (Read less)

The role of ALK in the development of human cancer has been established by a number of studies. However, the function of ALK in the development of zebrafish, a model organism for cancer research, is unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK are activated by zebrafish ALKALs, which in turn, are involved in the development of zebrafish iridophores. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development and suggest a role of ALK in the development of human cancer.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during a critical period of development. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of a disease that has had a profound impact on human history. (Abridged)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to be a major source of greenhouse gas emissions. However, the management of grasslands can also be a powerful tool to mitigate climate change. This study shows that the management of grasslands can be a powerful tool to mitigate climate change. We show that the management of grasslands can be a powerful tool to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses in order to inform public health interventions. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We developed a web tool, SpillOver, that provides a comparative risk assessment of zoonotic and nonzoonotic viruses, enabling policy makers and health scientists to identify and prioritize targets for research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and control of future viral threats.

Nectar is the reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of colorful nectar are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that underlie the evolution of colorful nectar and the role that alkaloids may play in this process.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of demographic events, including the arrival of new populations and the spread of new diseases. The impact of these events on the genetic structure of the continent is not well understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the Early Medieval period. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly modern, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that the history of Europe is more complex than previously thought and that the impact of complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. (PsycINFO Database Record

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in other resource-scarce settings. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the assembly of a complex sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), to the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme. This results in the formation of a replication fork that is capable of synthesizing DNA in the presence of a template. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the human genome. This work also provides a unique perspective on the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. The hypothesis that life began with the emergence of RNA is the most widely accepted explanation for the origin of life. In this work, we demonstrate that RNA can replicate itself in the absence of proteins. This is a critical step toward the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic outcomes of individuals and communities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is less well known. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of metal homeostasis in fungi and the role of fungal natural products in microbial interactions. The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary setting is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph that is not stable at the present-day conditions on Earth. The sedimentary setting for the tridymite at Gale crater is also unique, as it is associated with a silicic volcanic source. The sedimentary setting and the presence of a silicic volcanic source for the sedimentary silica polymorphs at Gale crater are consistent with the geologic history of the region and the formation of the “Lake Gale” deposits.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to the ongoing climate change, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly induce colitis in a mouse model, and that this requires the expression of the Th1 transcription factor T-bet. Moreover, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The role of the microbiome in the transmission of infectious diseases is a rapidly emerging field of study. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its transmission. We demonstrate that A. phagocytophilum induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic framework for the role of the microbiome in vector-mediated disease transmission. This work also highlights the potential for pathogens to use host proteins to manipulate the microbiome and enhance transmission. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of flight. However, the study of the early history of the tail is hindered by the lack of fossils. Here, we describe a new species of early bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, that fills an important gap in the history of the tail. This species shows that the tail of early birds was more similar to that of nonavian dinosaurs than previously thought, and that the tail was adapted to life in dense forest environments.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is used by animals to blend in with their environment, to attract mates, or to warn predators. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the mechanism is the same in all cases.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to survive in hypoxic regions of the tumor microenvironment is a key factor in the development of the disease. We show that hypoxia induces the expression of a gene, NANOG, which encodes a key factor in the maintenance of pluripotency in embryonic stem cells. We also show that this effect is mediated by hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the proportion of breast cancer cells that possess the cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bibles were produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We find that the source of the parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, as has been suggested in the past, but rather the use of more than one species of mammal. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used in the production of other ancient manuscripts.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well established. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in a variety of biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs, and this epigenetic regulation is mediated by RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3). These findings provide insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we show that the D614G mutation has little effect on the structure of the spike. However, we find that the G614 mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may have a significant impact on the infectivity of the virus. This work provides a detailed structural understanding of the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure of the spike and may inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics.
