We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on racial and ethnic minority groups and the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to this disparity.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of fundamental importance in the understanding of the chemical world. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we provide a quantitative description of this phenomenon. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This work is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the chemical world under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the magnitude of this effect is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, such as those caused by population growth and development, can reduce fire activity, which in turn reduces warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emission scenarios, highlighting the importance of human activities in driving fire regimes. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but that this effect is offset by other changes in land use and fire activity. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon cycle.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. The symbionts provide essential nutrients to their hosts, and the hosts provide a suitable environment for the microbes to thrive. However, the mechanisms that regulate the activities of these microbial communities are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts of a symbiotic organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the glycan catabolism is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their symbiotic microbes. This may be particularly important in the case of the bioluminescent symbionts of Euprymna scolopes, which are dependent on the provision of a specific glycan at a specific time of day.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which we combine with a sparse representation of word embeddings. Our method is particularly well-suited to text data with a narrative structure, such as crime reports. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This method can be applied to any domain, and we expect it to be useful in many areas, including social science, medicine, and business.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period of time is characterized by a lack of knowledge about the origin of the disease and its reservoirs. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated, and that this correlation was the main driver of the reintroduction of the bacterium into Europe. Our results provide evidence for repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors, which were the main entry points for the disease into Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the second plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important in the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for humans, with a wide range of uses in the food, pharmaceutical, and cosmetics industries. The recent mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific coast of North America is a major threat to the ecosystem and to the economic value of this resource. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus and that it is spreading in the marine environment. This finding provides a mechanism for the spread of the disease and for the potential for the virus to spread to other areas and to other species.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. View Full-Text

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the population is not homogeneous, but rather shows a geographic influence on the present genomic diversity. These results are important for the understanding of the human history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. Although the crop rating data reflect the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop condition index can be used to provide early warning of crop production anomalies, and thus can be used to improve agricultural decision-making and food security.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our understanding of the response of soil respiration to warming across a range of biomes. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and find that soil respiration rates do not increase with experimental warming in all biomes. Moreover, we find that soil respiration rates follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key example of the interplay between natural selection and the constraints imposed by the genome itself. We show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a hallmark of the evolution of the plant kingdom, is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome. This is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the number of genes, a change in the structure of the genome, and the establishment of a new lifestyle. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the genome and the origin of the plant kingdom.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a quantitative assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought and its future intensification. It also provides a tool for assessing the impact of climate change on water resources in SSA. This work is important for water resource managers, policy makers, and the general public.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was one of the most significant scientific events of the 20th century. The discovery of quasicrystals in the red trinitite, the glassy material that formed from the sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines, is a significant scientific event of the 21st century.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy into chemical energy that is used by all living organisms. The biosynthesis of the pigments that capture the light energy is a highly conserved process, and the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is one of the most important steps in this process. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is catalyzed by three classes of enzymes, and that the evolution of these enzymes is linked to the evolution of photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of inflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS and other neurodegenerative diseases.

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. These findings are important because they show that the probability of drought is increasing because of human activities, and that this increase is likely to be exacerbated by additional global warming.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the autism spectrum disorder and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling and homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SO(2)) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1, and show that these mutations cause a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates can be monitored in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease, and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by neurons. We also show that the spreading of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in neurons, demonstrating that the internalization of aggregates is important for the spreading of aggregates and disease progression. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to the emergence of zoonotic viruses from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein that is highly concentrated in the bat salivary gland and found that this protein inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunosuppressant protein. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the bat salivary gland in the emergence of zoonotic viruses. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2, which blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also report the discovery of a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer with a high incidence of one-carbon deficiency. These findings provide a rationale for the development of a class of drugs that target the metabolic needs of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a hallmark of the disease. Here, we show that the inclusions contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. However, we observe that the proteins that form inclusions are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have broad impact on the field of atom optics and many-body physics.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a period of global cooling and a reduction in plant diversity. However, this paper shows that the Cretaceous was a time of great diversification of plants, including the origin of aquatic plants. The study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous aquatic angiosperm, shows that aquatic plants were common in the Cretaceous and that they may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in virology, but the rate at which they evolve is still debated. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvoviruses, which are the oldest known human viruses. We find that the rate of evolution of these viruses is an order of magnitude lower than previously thought, and we are able to date the origin of the human parvovirus lineage to ∼12.6 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This work also provides a unique resource for future studies of ancient viruses.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global change. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of the melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets and the expansion of the oceans as the climate has warmed.

Pain is a common experience, but the experience of pain is changing. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing with age in America, but that the increase is not uniform across the population. We find that pain is increasing with age for those with less education, but not for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the structure and reactivity of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This picture reveals the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The results are used to understand why the natural substrate indole is able to react, while the isostere benzimidazole does not. The results are also used to highlight the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the available treatment options are limited. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of developing effective antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most complex and important interactions in nature. The molecular mechanisms that regulate these associations are poorly understood, and the role of the host’s glycan metabolism in shaping these associations is unknown. Here, we show that the host squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the metabolic products to modify the conditions of their habitat. This work provides a mechanistic link between glycan metabolism and the regulation of symbiosis, and it suggests that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their associated microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. Understanding the mechanisms of host-microbial interactions may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling the activities of microbes in the environment and in the human body. This paper describes a series of experiments that show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases to enter cells and to activate the fusion reaction that releases the viral genome into the cell cytoplasm. We show that the cleavage of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins is required for infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection of other cell types. These findings suggest that the sequential cleavage of MERS-CoV S proteins is a determinant of its virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and thus on climate change. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. The results suggest that this intervention could have a significant impact on the sustainability of the food system.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and the presence of this interface may contribute to the immune evasion and immune suppression activities of this protein. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read less)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in the cortex. We also show that this hypoxia-induced edema is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this condition. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a consequence of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data (the dataset) to find the strongest associations.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood and are essential for the formation of blood vessels. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the development of ECs has been limited to the laboratory. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for ischemic disorders. Furthermore, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study may also lead to the development of a new treatment for ischemic disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The discovery of the ligand for the orphan RTK, ALK, has led to the identification of a number of other orphan RTKs that are involved in a variety of diseases. Here, we show that the ligand for ALK, ALKAL1, is involved in the development of the zebrafish eye and that the ligand for the other orphan RTK, Ltk, is involved in the development of the zebrafish pigment cells.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major global health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well established, the underlying molecular bases for insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human and animal morbidity and mortality. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (PsycINFO Database Record

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our findings provide a mechanistic insight into the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, the frequency and intensity of wildfires in the United States has increased substantially over the past several decades, and is now a major threat to the economy and environment. This increase is largely due to human activities, such as land use changes, fire suppression, and the use of fire by humans. We show that human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has increased fire risk to the economy and environment.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic outcomes of individuals and communities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that have been used for pest control for thousands of years. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time to detectable plasma viral load is very sensitive to the rate of viral production, and that the rate of viral production is likely to be rapid. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, and that the timing of treatment is critical. These results can inform the design of clinical trials for ZIKV. (Abridged)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the maintenance of homeostasis. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and the majority of patients die from the disease. The identification of mechanisms that contribute to the development of resistance to treatment may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is induced by chemotherapy and that this expression is associated with the development of resistance to treatment. Furthermore, we show that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still debated. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries for food security. Our analysis highlights the need for improved management of river fisheries, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide lead to a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the nervous system, and the ability to regenerate in the adult mammalian CNS is lost with age. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in neuronal regeneration.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the diversity of life. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant component of metabolic activity in the resting brain is topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), a network of low-activity regions that is thought to be active during the resting state. In Parkinson’s disease, the DMN-like dominant component of metabolic activity was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. The dominant component of metabolic activity was reduced in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and partially restored by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant component of metabolic activity was already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. We show that there is a second 5′ modification in yeast, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. This modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We propose that this modification is produced cotranscriptionally and that it could modulate the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also provide evidence that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We demonstrate that the biodiversity effect on ecosystem functioning is driven by the thermal tolerance of species, and that this is the primary driver of the observed changes in the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning as temperatures change. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species in the context of global warming, and suggest that the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning may be exacerbated by environmental warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of place memories, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons in MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and their functional coupling, which will be useful for future studies of the functional role of this region in navigation. Dodder is a root- and leafless plant that parasitizes a large number of autotrophic plants. Dodder is able to synchronize its flowering with the flowering of its hosts. This study shows that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation in a parasite, which may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the dodder to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatal pathway form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of their parent cell bodies in the ventral tegmental area. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Within the bouquets, striosomal fibers are found to be tightly intertwined with the dopamine-containing dendrites and also with afferents labeled by glutamatergic, GABAergic, and cholinergic markers and markers for astrocytic cells and fibers and connexin 43 puncta. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets form specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we are socialized to believe that the way we connect with others is through a shared sense of understanding. But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We asked people to talk with each other and to rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. These cells are located in the wall of the right atrium and are responsible for maintaining a regular heart rate. The heart rate is regulated by a number of factors, including the autonomic nervous system and hormones. In this study, we show that the activity of these cells is regulated by a number of factors, including the activity of the autonomic nervous system and hormones. This regulation is important for maintaining a regular heart rate and for preventing arrhythmias.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant defense has been debated. Here, we show that Si can enhance resistance against insect herbivores by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect crops from insect attack. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Abridged)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic substances in the environment. Thus, plants are highly susceptible to toxic substances in the environment. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver functional biomolecules to plants, which can be used to deliver siRNAs to plants to silence a gene of interest. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step forward in the development of a new class of tools for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides a wide range of goods and services to society. However, the coastal zone is also a highly vulnerable ecosystem, as it is often the first area to be impacted by nutrient pollution. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to the coastal zone. This finding is important because it suggests that nutrient management efforts should not be limited to large watersheds, but should also include small tributaries. Our findings have implications for coastal management and restoration, as well as for the protection of valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes thermodynamic work available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed fine-tuned properties of the universe today. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the design of chemical networks.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause a wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, and that these abnormalities can be explained by changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to seizures in a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms underlying the wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities that can be caused by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the wide range of clinical presentations that can be caused by NMDAR-Abs. This framework may also be useful for understanding the mechanisms underlying the clinical presentations of other autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. The history of carbon perturbation events is critical for understanding the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to a near doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over a large area and to an increase in nutrient fluxes within an icehouse. These results provide insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming and the potential for such events to occur in the future.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in reducing deforestation, but also the need for certification to be part of a broader suite of policies to protect forests. This work also highlights the importance of monitoring and enforcement of certification standards. (Abridged)

The exocyst complex is a protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce the sex phenotype. Here we show that the genetic basis of sex determination in a cichlid fish can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, and we discuss the evolutionary consequences of this modularity.

The retina is challenged by a variety of factors that can lead to photoreceptor cell death. One of these factors is the accumulation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a precursor of the damaging reactive oxygen species-generating lipofuscin. We show that the intracellular level of iron can influence the fate of A2E. We also show that the Fe chelator deferiprone can reduce the oxidation and degradation of A2E. These findings have implications for the treatment of retinal diseases, including age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional adaptations in separate structures. Here we show that this is not the case in the cnidarian clade siphonophores, which use specialized side branches (tentacles) armed with nematocysts for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological changes in the tentacles and nematocysts, and that these changes are linked to prey type. Our findings help to understand the evolution of specialization and morphological diversification in food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The fossil record of the hominin hand is fragmentary, and the evolution of the modern human hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Abridged)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2, which blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also report the discovery of a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer with a high incidence of one-carbon deficiency. These findings provide a rationale for the development of a class of drugs that target the metabolic needs of cancer.

This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is important because, in low- and middle-income countries, the majority of people obtain their vitamin A from food sources. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security that considers the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of the global economy, but it is also a major contributor to the loss of soil productivity. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but the increase in vehicle weight has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
